Coordination at all levels and with all stakeholders will be continuous throughout the project duration, and the implementation will be monitored and eventually evaluated to ensure the best application of the implementation methods and to gradually improve work quality. Implementation Plan ANNEX 01. All activities will be implemented taking in consideration the SNFI cluster’s recommendations for COVID-19, especially in: registration points, dealing with BNFs, contractors, workers and IRD staff (physical distancing, sanitizers, masks and gloves, replacing pens, raising awareness banners in a visible place and a suitable hand-washing point at each site) IRD coordinated with each of Bonyan, Binaa, and SDI as they declared their intention to apply for shelter activity for the same allocation, there was no overlapping either in activities or locations Coordination emails are in ANNEX 26-27-28. IRD identified Suran sub-district as the relocation plan's target if needed

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Lifesaving emergency and winter support through Cash and GIK distribution for the newly displaced and returnees in NWS.

description.narrative:
the project at hand aims to contribute to the emergency amp winter response by applying a flexible approach that allows Violet to cover the needs in a timely manner and appropriate modality. it aims to help the most vulnerable coping with the displacement amp harsh winter conditions through implementing the following activities 1. ِِAddressing the needs of 3166 HHs for essential NFIs by the distribution of new arrival kits and/or cash for NFIs (120$). the new arrival kit was designed based on the SNFI cluster guidance and cash amount was designed based on the SMEB
2. provision One-off winter cash (180$) provision for 3000 HHs. The winterization cash amount was designed based on the SNFI cluster guidance but also based on the lessons learned from previous projects to cover heating fuel needs of 5-members HH (4 liters of fuel/day) for 60 days in the winter. while designing the cash amount, Violet took considered the fuel price differences between winter and summer ( according to REACH, average fuel price in the last winter was 0.75 USD, while the average price in summer is 0.45 USD). The cash value was discussed with CWG and SNFI. However, Violet will adopt the SNFI and CWG recommendations in case of any change. winterization cash will also contribute to mitigating the risk of storing fuel for a long time by BNF. Additionally, based on the WASH cluster recommendations, each BNF HH will receive 750 g of soap sufficient for 1 month to contribute to COVID-19 response
Cash modality was selected to allow BNFs to secure their needs in a dignified and flexible way. Moreover, it contributes to market recovery through disposing of cash in the market and may create new job opportunities the project will focus on the newly IDPs in the areas that have been identified with the highest needs, and hosting newly IDPs who fled their homes as a result of GOS offensive, but also the returnees and IDPs who returned to their original communities, or communities of displacement. moreover, winter cash support will be implemented in the areas with a high percentage of damaged shelters like Sarmin, Ariha amp Atareb (According to HNAP report for April 2020) since the IDPs and returnees who living in damaged buildings are the most vulnerable and not protected against the harsh winter conditions. both groups will be targeted as they are the most vulnerable groups to the shocks. BNFs will be nominated by the community representatives based on the selection criteria including displacement and returning duration taking into account prioritizing women-headed HHs, HHs with children, elderlies, PWD, pregnant, and lactating women Violet will ensure close coordination with the other actors and SNFI/ CCCM clusters to ensure the coordinated response and to avoid potential overlapping. it also confirms its readiness to immediately start the implementation as soon as the SGA is signed since it is in the final stage of contracting with the new arrival kits supplier, and also has FWA for MTA services and transportation, which will be utilized under this project. The contractors and MTA have been identified through competitive bidding process based on their experience, accessibility, and financial offer. While the NFI kits and cash coupons will be distributed by Violet teams, the MTA will be responsible for redeeming the BNFs coupons. Before cash distribution, RNA, and market assessment in terms of availability of the NFIs, their prices, and the accessibility will be conducted to ensure the markets are functioning and all BNFs have good and equal access markets. In order to ensure the selection criteria are respected and to avoid terrorism financing, fraud, and Forgery, cash coupons will be equipped with light thermal stickers. Moreover, the verification and antiterrorism check (ATC) will be conducted for all cash BNFs Finally, Violet will ensure the COVID-19 preventive measures, accountability and SEA mitigation measures are applied.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improving Living Conditions of the Conflict-affected Population in Northwest Syria through NFI and Winterization Assistance.

description.narrative:
This project aims to respond to the needs of conflict-affected IDPs and the most vulnerable people of the host community (70% IDPs and 30% host community) in Idleb and Afrin districts, by providing life-saving NFI and winterization assistance through the following components:
a) providing vulnerable 1000 households (5000 individuals approx.) in Afrin and Janderes sub-districts with in-kind essential Non-Food Item kits that will include the following materials chosen based on the S/NFI Cluster guidance: plastic sheets, jerry cans, solar lamps, sleeping mats, blankets, and hasira/carpet. The procurement of the NFI kits will be done in Turkey, and this will avoid impacting the local markets and any potential increase of local prices. This component will mainly target IDPs who have not received any similar assistance during the last displacement. This component will be implemented during the first three months of the project (distribution, including procurement, to take place in July-September period).
b) distribution of restricted vouchers for heating fuel needed during the winter season in 2020 in Afrin, and Janderes in Aleppo governorate and Kafr Takharim, Armanaz and Maaret Tmisreen in Idleb. Winterization activity will target 2800 HHs (14,000 individuals) of both IDPs (70%) and HCs (30%) with 2 restricted vouchers for two rounds during winter months (December 2020 and January 2021) total value of the vouchers will be 120 USD (two vouchers: each with 60 USD value). This was determined based on the SNFI winter guidance and coordination with and preference of the SNFI Cluster, where the average need per household in NWS is 4 L of fuel daily, or 10 kg of coal per day for continuous 60 days minimum. This will ensure reaching more beneficiaries during the harsh winter season. Shafak will conduct an assessment in the targeted locations to identify the type of stoves the targeted beneficiaries are using to determine the suitable type of heating fuel (diesel, or charcoal), and contract with suppliers accordingly. As for voucher printing, it will be procured from Turkey, and transferred to Syria (transfer of goods to the final delivery point, Shafak office in Bab Al-Hawa, will be a condition in the contracts with the printing vendors, who use commercials border crossings - Shafak already has experience in such procurement). The modality of restricted vouchers has been chosen to ensure that targeted beneficiaries will use the vouchers only for intended assistance (fuel/charcoal for heating).
c) Distribution of soap bars (six pieces - 125g each) to enhance beneficiaries' prevention against COVID-19 these items will be distributed along with each of the above components.
In total, this project intends to reach 3800 households (19000 individuals: 4,470 men, 4,886 women, 4,470 boys, 5,175 girls) focusing on IDP sites such as unfinished buildings, collective centers and informal settlements. Shafak selected these communities based on the following: a) IDPs movement tracking, b) accessibility, c) safety and d) needs identified by Shafak. Shafak will prioritize the most vulnerable groups (e.g. women-headed HHs, HHs with members with chronic diseases, elderlies, ...etc. refer to the attached selection criteria.
The beneficiaries will be selected based on a set of vulnerability criteria with a focus on the newly IDPs who left their hometowns during the last displacement and are in dire need of winterization and NFI assistance.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improve the living conditions of conflict-affected populations through repairing of damaged houses and providing winterization needs while enhancing referral mechanisms to ensure accessibility and privacy for vulnerable groups in NW Syria

description.narrative:
This project contributes to life-sustaining assistance to the most vulnerable groups in Northwest Syria Idleb governorate sub-districts of Dana and Qourqeena through the following two interventions that designed based on attached Need Assessment (Attachment.1):
Firstly, provision house repairing for /600/ of partly damaged houses—Grade 2 for the IDPs and host communities (include 782 men, 836 women, 664 boys, and 718 girls). HLP due diligence will be included in implementation in order to achieve as much legal certainty about tenure as possible to ensure the security of tenure by verifying the ownership of the land or shelter and to prevent the exploitation and eviction of the IDPs. The percentage of IDPs will be 60%, and the rest will be from the host communities. Contractor- modality will be adopted of repairing houses, this modality supports an accountable, timely, and efficient use of resources while protecting the rights of the beneficiaries.
Secondly, provision winterization assistance (diesel stoves with accessories, diesel fuel) for the most vulnerable people 1350 HHs (include 1755 men, 1890 women, 1485 boys, and 1620 girls), 80% of the IDPs who living (outside camps) in the makeshift shelter or in damaged/unfinished buildings and they did not receive winter assistance in the past, also 20% of them host communities who meet the vulnerability criteria to avoid the sensitive. All the beneficiaries will be selected based on the vulnerability criteria, so the blanket distributions will be avoided. The in-kind- modality will be adopted for distributions of the fuel and stoves. Diesel fuel was chosen for heating because it is the most common and available in the targeted areas, it is most efficient and relatively safe, so vulnerable HHs can install the stoves and use it easily, also it will be useful in cooking food in addition to heating. SRD will purchase them from local markets for revitalization, and will be responsible for quality control.
During the life of the project, SRD outreach workers will ensure that all vulnerable groups are involved in project activities, and will accompany the shelter teams during the door to door verification to detect of vulnerability cases in the beneficiaries' houses and refer them to nearby SRD community centers to respond (Attachment.2). In addition, they will ensure that technical assessments conducted by shelter teams meet the demand of persons with disabilities and the elderly. Also, they will deliver awareness messages for beneficiaries who receiving the winterization assistance to protect from COVID-19 and ensuring that the distribution process in line with protection principles.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing emergency nutrition, health, and protection services for displaced children under 5 and PLWs by establishing 8 RRTs in addition to one OTP

description.narrative:
This project will cover 85,000 people, disaggregated as follows: - 29,750 PLWs - 55,250 Children under 5
One OTP center and 8 rapid response teams (RRTs) will be maintained and will continue to provide services in Idleb gt Idleb gt Maaret Tamsrin gt Kelly (OTP) Idleb gt Harim gt Dana gt Qah (RRTs)
Each Rapid response team (RRT) will work in specific locations and will cover (pregnant and lactating women and children under 5)
These Rapid response teams will work in parallel and in coordination with the available health facilities in the target areas. The RRTs will provide integrated health, nutrition, child protection, and hygiene promotion.
Nurses will screen the children under 5 and refer the ones with dangers signs and medical problems to the available health facilities.
Community Health Workers (CHWs) will assess and screen nutritional status among the children under 5 and distribute nutritional supplies to them where needed. Also, the infant and young child feeding practices in emergencies (IYCF-E) services will be provided to prevent any case of malnutrition by:
- Counseling the PLWs and caregivers of children under 24 months of age and providing messages on IYCF-E recommended practices to mothers who have malnourished children. - Distributing micronutrients and nutrition supplies for the PLWs and children. - Reporting to the cluster any distribution of breast milk substitute.
Midwives will screen pregnant and lactating women and refer the ones with any danger signs or medical problems to the nearest facilities.
Also, a pre and rapid coordination combined with referrals will be in place if the team notices or identifies any sign of abuse or violence among children under 5 and or mothers. All cases of violence against women and children will be referred to a pre-identified center.
Continue to support the OTP center in Kelly PHC Maaret Tamsrin. This facility will provide treatment of severe acute malnutrition (without complications) for all boys and girls under 5 and IYCF counseling will be provided to their mothers. This response will adopt the recommendation of the cluster in COVID-19 context to minimize the risk of infection for staff and beneficiaries through:
- Mercy-USA will apply recommended IPC measures at RRTs sites - IYCF-E counseling and messages could be conducted via WhatsApp - Screen and isolate all beneficiaries with suspected COVID-19 at entrance point of OTP site. -Dissemination of information on COVID-19 signs, symptoms and IPC measures -All other needed measures will apply according to the cluster recommendation
Also, this project will involve empowering mothers and HH members through training to screen their own children for malnutrition by teaching them how to use color-coded Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) tapes and check for oedema.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving integrated Nutrition community-based services for the people in need in North-West Syria through activation of RRTs

description.narrative:
This project aims to address nutrition, health, and hygiene-promoting sectors. Qatar charity with SRD as a partner will provide critically needed and integrated services which focus on life-saving nutritional needs of children U5 and PLWs for both IDPs and Host communities in targeted areas in Aleppo/ Jarablus and Al Ghandorah Sub-districts and Al-Bab/ Ar-Ra’ee and A’rima subdistricts through establishing 5 Rapid Response Teams that will provide follow up screening, treatment for MAM and SAM cases, and providing counseling for the caregiver with all precautions and needed PPEs against COVID-19 as follows: 1- MUAC screening for children (Boys and Girls) under the age of 5 and for pregnant and lactating women in Azaz, Al Bab and Jarablus/Aleppo.
2- referrals of malnourished cases, Children U5 with serious signs and Medical problems, PLWs with Medical problems, disabled beneficiaries, and also identifying any signs or marks of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs and referring them to the respective treatment centers.
3- Holding IYCF-E awareness session on feeding practices, Hand Washing, in addition to one-to-one IYCF-E counselling, nutrition communication, and social mobilization messages.
4- Distribute micro-nutrients/nutrition supplements for preventing anemia and malnutrition among children (Boys and Girls) under the age of 5 and for pregnant and lactating women Jarablus and Al Ghandorah Subdistricts and Al Bab/ Ar-Ra’ee and A’rima subdistricts.
5-Registering all screened cases and reporting to the nutritionists and data entry team members.
6- Monitor distribution and use of breast milk substitutes
7-provide counseling for Mothers with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 and isolating them at home and advising them to continue recommended feeding practices by taking into account necessary hygiene precautions during feeding.
8-Providing Programmes and services to protect, promote and support optimal breastfeeding (early and exclusive), and age-appropriate and safe complementary foods and feeding practices and they should remain a critical component of the programming and response for young children in the context of COVID-19.
9. Capacity building and supervision after training: RRTs training package (IYCF-E and CMAM with COVID-19).
Each RRT will consist of "nutritionist amp 2 CHWs amp Data entryamp nurse and midwife.
Additionally, the project will include the appropriate monitoring of the planned services. The monitoring and reporting activity will allow QC to conduct proper implementation and evaluation and forecast the needed services or gaps for future activities.
The proposed intervention was designed to respond to life-saving nutrition needs in areas experiencing high severity of need. Specifically, QC will support nutrition services in Northern Aleppo, with services focusing on the most vulnerable (women, children, and persons with disabilities).
The integration and understanding the roles of both parties (QC and SRD) will benefit the communities with high impacts, the pre-existing of SRD teams in the mentioned areas plus the high speed and flexibility of QC and the presence of it's centers as a base for teams. On the other hand, QC had a great experience and familiarity in the targeted locations, while SRD was the strategic implementing partner in the mentioned area for more than two years with great relationships with all local authorities.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing lifesaving preventive and curative nutrition services for vulnerable population groups with attention to children and women with special needs in NW Syria

description.narrative: This project aims to continue and increase the accessibility to essential life-saving curative and preventative nutrition services for all age and sex groups boys, girls, pregnant and lactating women and other caregivers (other women, and men) with attention to people with special needs without any sexual discrimination, among IDPs and host communities, in NW Syria. Where the project will provide nutrition services for 28800 PLWs and 60768 children under five years (80569 IDPs and 8999 HCs) (1800 PWDs). Through this project, SDI is going to: Scale-up and continue the integrated mother and child-centered nutrition life-saving interventions Scale-up and continue supporting the optimal infant feeding and caring practices in an emergency, optimal maternal nutrition, and micronutrient interventions. Fill the current service gaps in high needs and remote locations through providing emergency integrated health, nutrition, WASH, and child protection rapid services through Rapid Response teams (RRT). Continue and strengthen the existing program for managing acute malnutrition among children under five and PLWs. The scope of interventions will include: 1st:Scaling up integrated nutrition response support through 7 Rapid Response teams which will be dispatched to the areas of high IDP flow (2 in Afrin subdistrict in Aleppo governorate, 1 in Marret Tamisrin, 3 in dana, and 1 in Salqin in Idleb governorate), to provide the following activities: Screening 50400 children 6-59 months, and 24192 PLWs, referral and follow up who are malnourished. Provide emergency IYCF counseling for 7750 caregivers including PLWs. Disseminating messages on IYCF-E recommended feeding practices, for 37000 caregivers including PLWs. Distributing micronutrients for preventing anemia and malnutrition among 25000 children and PLWs. Screen, referral CU5 and PLWs with dangers signs and Medical problems Support hygiene promotion and rising WASH awareness by providing Key messages to prevent the risk of COVID 19 transmission and other infections. Identify visual signs of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs during Nutrition screening. 2nd: Continue functioning of the OTP-SFP services in two fixed CMAM centers in Afrin and Salqin subdistricts. Nutrition status and anthropometric measurements of 14976 children under five and PLW are regularly screened, recorded, reported, and required program actions are taken, treatment 90 children under five with SAM without medical complications, treatment 605 children under five and PLWs with MAM. 3th: Capacity building of 48 frontline nutrition services providers on IYCF-E and CMAM programs in the context of COVID-19. As a part to COVID 19 response, SDI is going to apply adjustments of the nutrition activities to mitigate the risk of infection while ensuring continuity of life-saving nutrition services, where SDI is going to integrate key messages on hygiene and COVID-19 symptoms, and (IPC) measures, implement a simplified protocol for the treatment of acute malnutrition, use a separate MUAC tape for each child and PLW, use MUAC and/or edema only for admission and discharge, reduce the frequency of follow-up visits to 1 every 4 weeks, distribute micronutrients for two months in advance if available, screen and isolate, refer suspected COVID-19 cases, applying recommended IPC and triage measures, provide IYCF-E counseling, either at the appropriate distance of 2 meters apart or remotely by phone or video and disseminate IYCF-E messages use platforms such as text messages and WhatsApp videos, posters in public places. As well as, SDI will train the caregivers on MUAC and edema screening, referral, recognize signs of deterioration, and give them a mobile or WhatsApp number of the CHW to contact in case the child’s condition deteriorates. SDI will receive the needed nutrition supplies for this project from UNICEF through PAC organization and from WFP.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving Nutrition services for the PIN through 1 stabilization center and RRTs in Dana subdistrict

description.narrative:
The arrival of about 840,000 IDPs to the areas near the Syrian-Turkish border has resulted an insufficient access to curative and preventive nutrition services, and this requiring interventions to ensure continuity of existing nutrition services and increased coverage of services for treatment of acute malnutrition (SAM and MAM) among children aged 6-59 months in addition to increase the delivery of life-saving nutrition services in high needs locations. The project will scale up the existing nutrition services for CU5 and PLW to fill the gaps (according to Nutrition cluster plan) in the high severity communities and IDPs hosting areas in Dana subdistrict, which are being provided with nutrition services including our OTP center, Stabilization center and 6 RRTs, the nutrition activities in this project will be implemented by 1 stabilization center located in Sarmada children’s hospital which considered as a key referral pediatric hospital for health and nutrition cases in Dana subdistrict, and 6 extra rapid response teams (RRTs) will cover the community of Sarmada and more than 50 IDPs camps (Main locations: Burdaqly camps, Bab El Hawa camps, Wadi Abaas camps, Tal Elkarameh camps, Babisqa camps amp Burj Elnumra camps) through: A. 6 RRTs cover the gaps in the communities of Sarmada, Bab El Hawa, Burdaqly and Burj Elnumra, each team will be consisted of 1 nutritionist, 2 CHW, 1 nurse and 1 data entry, these teams will work on: - Screening and referral of children under 5 (CU5) and pregnant and lactating women (PLW) with dangers signs and medical problems to the OTP and SC centers. - Providing emergency infant and young child feeding (IYCF-E) counseling and disseminating messages on IYCF-E recommended feeding practices. - Distributing micronutrients for preventing of anaemia and malnutrition among children and pregnant, lactating women for the far communities and non able to be referred cases. - Registering all screened cases and reporting to the nutritionists and data entry team members. - Nutrition Supplements distribution. - Disseminating messages (IEC/BCC) on IYCF-E recommended feeding practices amp rising awareness about COVID-19 pandemic. - Identifying the abused cases among boys and girls 6-59 months, pregnant and lactating women to be referred to child protection partners to take an action.
B. Stabilization center in Sarmada children's hospital: Scale up the center with 10 extra beds with one more resident pediatrician and 3 nurses to cover the expansion of the center to have 20 beds in total, the center has now 10 beds and runs by 1 pediatrician, 1 Nutritionist, 3 nurses (1 nurse every 8 hours, 3 shifts) and 1 data Entry , 3 cleaners, covers inpatient services on daily 24/7, providing daily assessment and management of inpatient pediatrics for SAM with complications. The staff of the center and the RRTs is qualified and trained in many topics in nutrition cluster.
So the project will contribute in covering the urgent gaps through scaling up the nutrition services in Dana sub-district and will play a role in facing chronic Malnutrition (Stunting) at the long term beyond the project end.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing support to the continuation of lifesaving preventive and curative nutrition services in northwest Syria

description.narrative:
QRCS aims through the proposed project to ensure the continuity and increase the coverage of life-saving preventive and curative nutrition services among children under 5 (boys and girls) and PLWs at health facility levels, running by QRCS and other NGOs, also at the community levels. QRCS has been supporting seven fixed OTPs centers and two mobile rapid response teams reported on monthly 4Ws since 2016 in collaboration with partners and with coordination with health and nutrition clusters, UN agencies, health directorates, and local stakeholders in which targeted areas are ranked as high severity according to the HNO 2020 and nutrition cluster reports, at 12 sites of IDPs camps and 10 communities in Idleb and rural Aleppo.
QRCS and partners will continue provision of curative and preventative nutrition services through running seven OTPs centers, two mobile rapid response teams and deployment of community outreach activities in the targeted areas in Idleb and rural Aleppo, as well as QRCS, will implement programmatic adjustment in the context of COVID-19 to protect health care providers, mitigate the risk of infection and ensure continuity of life-saving nutrition services as the followings: 1- Continuity of life-saving nutrition services particularly CMAM, micronutrient supplementation, and IYCF-E under guidance for adaptations in the context of COVID-19. 2- Facility and community-based nutritional assessment for PLWs and children under 5 by MUAC and Z-scores using innovative application and technology to upload validated and verified data. 3- Deployment of two mobile rapid response teams: MUAC screening and referral complicated SAM cases and provision of therapeutic for SAM and MAM cased among children 6-59 months and malnourished PLWs in 12 IDPs camps and 10 communities. 4- Provision of Maternal nutrition and appropriate IYCF-E counseling and messages for pregnant women and mothers. 5- 34 CHWs and 2 team leaders will conduct community outreach activities promoting on IYCF-E, Maternal nutrition, health, and WASH-related topics and massages based on NWS nutrition cluster and TWG recommendations in the context of COVID-19 using of additional platforms such as mobile text messages, radio, TV, and social media to protect, promote and support IYCF-E. 6- Distribution of micronutrient supplementary to PLWs and children under 5 based on SoPs and nutrition cluster recommendations. 7- Conduct training on IYCF-E and CMAM programming in the context of COVID-19 for facilities and community staff. 8- Conduct training on MUAC screening and referral and roll-out of a family MUAC approach in which caregivers, PLW, and family members.
During project cycle, QRCS will provide supportive supervision through community health leaders, field project coordinator and project management based in Turkey, as well as QRCS, will provide equitable access and quality of nutrition services the most vulnerable population among children under 5 (boys and girls) and PLWs reaching 127,800 expected beneficiaries including displaced population and overburdened and host communities. All estimated caseload and a number of targeted beneficiaries determined based on the capacity of QRCS and previous project finding, achievement and results which reported to nutrition cluster via monthly 4Ws (for more information and 4Ws reports see Annexes1,2,3,4,5 attached to support document section on GMS).

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Risk Education, ERW Contamination Impact Survey and VA Referral Case Management in NW Syria

description.narrative:
This project is consistent with HALO’s contribution to the 2020 HRP (ref: HSYR20-PRO-MIN-164140-1). It reflects lessons learned from HALO’s experience in NW Syria since 2016 amp consultation with the Mine Action Sub-Cluster (MASC), CCCM, Health amp Education clusters amp OCHA’s Access Working Group.
HALO will deliver a 12-month response, through direct implementation amp support from an implementing partner (iMFAD). The project includes Risk Education (RE), Explosive Remnants of War (ERW) Enhanced Contamination Impact Survey (ECIS), Victim Data Collection (VDC) amp Victim Assistance (VA) referral case management in selected districts across opposition-controlled areas of Idleb/western Aleppo amp Turkish-controlled areas of Aleppo. HALO will cover opposition-controlled areas, iMFAD will cover Turkish-controlled areas. The response is identical in both areas. Field staff will also be trained to deliver community COVID-19 awareness messaging consistent with WHO guidance. The project concept of operations is at Annex A (slide 8).
HALO will strengthen its presence in Gaziantep, reducing its presence in Amman. Project staff is 52 – 19 funded at 100% (HALO: 7, iMFAD: 6, contracted drivers: 6) - all in Syria amp 33 funded under shared arrangements (HALO: 23, iMFAD: 10). 32 of 52 staff are in NW Syria. The project organogram is at Annex B.
According to the 2020 HNO, ERW contamination increased by 29% from 2018 to 2019, with communities most at risk located near the frontlines of conflict and in urban centres. HALO’s extensive amp ongoing ECIS work in NW Syria confirms the ongoing threat posed by ERW. With official ERW disposal yet to commence in NW Syria, RE continues to plays a critical role in improving awareness amp reinforcing safe behavior amongst children amp adults.
2 x 5-person Community Liaison Teams (CLTs) (1 x HALO, 1 x iMFAD) will deliver standardized 30-40 min community-based RE sessions to children and adults, with content consistent with MASC key messaging. The priority will be IDPs in preparation for return to contaminated home communities. CLTs will also deliver training to Community Focal Points (CFPs) amp NGO Focal Points across all humanitarian sectors to improve the integration and reach of RE messaging. The total target is 19,760 beneficiaries (9,690 children, 9,690 adults amp 380 CFPs/NGO Focal Points). Beneficiary calculations are at Annex C.
CLTs will also provide ECIS support upon request (from other humanitarian actors amp local authorities) to identify, mark, report amp map ERW contamination in targeted districts. This activity is a continuation of HALO’s ERW survey work in NW Syria, which is scheduled to be completed by 31 Aug 2020.
Additionally, 3 x VA Case Management staff (2 x HALO, 1 x iMFAD), with support from CLTs, will collect amp analyse victim/survivor data from ERW amp other conflict-related accidents in order to identify referral requirements to specialised services. Case Management staff will ensure effective referral to relevant support services (as available), including transportation, amp maintain a relationship with referred beneficiaries throughout the process. This activity will enhance the resilience of people living with injuries amp disabilities (PLWD) and will complement other HALO projects with VA components (e.g. physiotherapy, prosthetics, psychosocial support, multi-purpose assistance). These efforts improve successful referral rates for survivors needing assistance, which indirectly relieves pressure on the Health cluster amp other clusters. The target is 285 interviews with a 50% successful referral rate for victims/survivors requiring assistance.
The project will be led by the combined HALO/iMFAD project office in Gaziantep, supported directly by HALO staff in Amman amp iMFAD staff in Balikesir. All field activities will be coordinated from HALO's Operation room in Amman.
The project has a Plan B, in order to mitigate key risks including access problems, security amp COVID.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integration of protection services into health facilities

description.narrative:
SAMS through this Project will scale up its integration of protection services (GP, GBV, and MA) into health facilities utilizing SAMS experience and success stories in the field of intervention in addition to the lessons learned collected throughout similar projects.
The planned PSS and GBV services will be integrated into 7 health facilities in Idleb and Aleppo governorates (Idleb Central Hospital, Alsahara PHC, Al-Ebzemo PHC, Alatareb Hospital, Batbu PHC, Aldana Hospital, and Sejjo Hospital) where a safe space (protection space) in each facility will be dedicated for those services. Each protection space will have 2 PSS workers + 1 GBV case Manager + 1 Case Worker, they will provide in center and outreach (GBV and GP) services including: Identification of cases GBV case management GBV prevention and awareness raising non GBV and non CP case management PSS monthly Protection monitoring surveys and Referrals to specialized services (CMR, HLP, Health, mental health, livelihoods, etc.,) Key messaging and awareness raising targeting beneficiaries in direct contact with humanitarian workers on the PSEA and community awareness for all protection concerns.
As for the MA component, it will be provided in two health facilities (Afrin (Alshifa’a) hospital, where SAMS currently providing VA services and plans to sustain the services through this project, Sejjo hospital, where SAMS took over the facility from another NGO and plan to reactivate the physiotherapy services for the survivor from explosive hazard. The VA team in each facility will consist of: 4 Physiotherapists + 4 PT assistants + 2 PSS workers, they will provide specialized services (PT and rehabilitation in addition to MHPSS services) for the survivors of explosive hazard accidents (both in center and outreach mobile services), Moreover, SAMS will refer the survivor to livelihoods service providers.
SAMS will follow all the precautionary measures as per SAMS COVID 19 PRP and in alignment with the COVID-19 Protection Cluster Recommendations and Observations on the Criticality of Protection Activities in NW Syria (March 2020) and Best experiences and practices in implementing GBV programs in the time of Covid-19. Furthermore, awareness against COVID 19 will be included in all community messages and awareness activities.
Finally, As an integral part of this approach, and in order to enhance the capacities and competencies of the PSS workers to improve the quality of the services provided through all protection cluster partners, SAMS is proposing a complementary activity that aims to assess the current capacity of the available PSS workers operating in NWS - including their educational background - where in coordination with the Protection cluster and Protection partners, SAMS to develop a PSWs capacity-building strategy for Northern Syria that will include the standards of the educational requirement for both PSWs and their trainers and the curriculum needed for qualifying those who work in the psychosocial support sector that will serve as a scientific method and technical reference that helps in providing a systematic service.
Protection services in SAMS intervention will be through MA (50%), GBV (25%), and GP (25%).

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Mitigating child protection risks for IDPs and the host community in northwestern Syria

description.narrative: According to draft of HNO 2020 issued by OCHA ,5.7 million children are in need of protection, with key need drivers including: ongoing exposure to hostilities, specifically in north-west and north-east Syria limited access to services and displacement, frequently separating children from family members, including primary caregivers, and disrupting education. 2.45 million children aged 5–17 are out of school, heightening their protection risks were reported to have been recruited by parties to the conflict. Cases of torture, detention, abduction, sexual violence, denial of and lack of access to humanitarian assistance due to lack of civil documentation, among other factors, were reported Incidents of girls and boys being married off at young ages and withdrawn from school in order to work, often in dangerous conditions, were also observed The needs assessment which have done by AHF indicate that there are vulnerability points with the children and primary care providers associated with the direct risks of worst forms of child labor, disability, physical / psychological injuries, severe neglect, family separation (including expected separation due to COVID19), child recruitment and child marriage. The project aims to reduce the protection risks for displaced children and the host community in northwestern Syria in line with the minimum standards for child protection by expanding the services provided at the AHF Center in Janoudiya by increasing the interventions of the following child protection activities: 1. Raise awareness between the women, men and children about CP issues through mobile teams 2. Implement case management services that address the children's vulnerabilities and primary care providers associated with the direct risks of the worst forms of child labor, disability, physical / psychological injuries, severe neglect, family separation (including expected separation due to COVID19), child recruitment and child marriage. These services will be provided by workers specialized in case management through the AHF Center 3. Building the capacities of child protection workers in case management. Child protection activities will be implemented in the Janoudiya area in Jisr Al-Shughour and the surround area, and the project will target host communities, IDPs and returnees, community centers and camps. The center will be served the most vulnerable children. All activities are in line with the Humanitarian Response Plan 2020 in addition to the strategic objectives of the Protection Cluster and the SCHF allocation paper. The services will be provided for one year The project will coordinate with the affected population and stakeholders and it had been designed to strengthen gender balance. The project aims to include children with special needs, and all activities will be carried out according to the recommendations of the protection cluster and WHO in order to deal with Covid-19 and the preventive measures required to protect beneficiaries and humanitarian workers. The project will be monitored by the MampE team, in order to monitor the progress of the project and ensure activities are implementing according to the work plan and agreed indicators. The project will ensure accountability of the affected population and stakeholders through transparency of accountability, the complaints mechanism, the feedback mechanism, and the monitoring of worker efficiency

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Reinforcement more safe, cohesive and accessible protection environment for crisis-affected and at-risk "MWBG" especially IDPs, and new returnees through providing quality and inclusive protection interventions (CP - GP - Mine Action) in Idlib, Ariha, and Al-Bab Sub-districts

description.narrative:
Project has designed based on recent updates in northwest of Syria, to cover 3 protection sub-clusters: CP, GP, MA, targeting the critical needs of IDPs and returnees in 7 communities: (Korin, Mastumeh, Idlib)in Ariha and Idlib sub-districts,(Hazwan, Sosyan, Al-Bab, Qabasin(Zamak)in Albab sub-district. Within project MWL will expand protection services through Korin protection center and 4 mobile teams to reach beneficiaries in 3 communities in Idlib. In addition to establish new community protection center in Al-Bab city and 4 mobile teams. Each mobile team contains 4 members: 1 team leader and 3 team workers(CP, GP, MA). Project will serve (85200) of most vulnerable (M:14550, W:19150, B:25350, G:26150) including (PWD:1440) through following protection interventions: 1- CP: targeting 27,360 of most vulnerable children, and their caregivers “M:1630, W:3230, B:10,850,G:11650), including CWD:925” through: full CM services amp Emergency Case Fund (ECF) Create and distribute videos contain the curriculum of structured PSS Conduct PSS activities and awareness-raising sessions Establish 8 child protection networks Provide training on communication and service delivery modality during COVID19 Establish CP Emergency focal point system in Al-Bab Sub-district to provide support of CP cluster materials distribution, referrals, and report to CP Monitoring group
2- GP: targeting 31,810 “M:9905, W:12905, B:4500, G:4500” especially PWD, elderly, persons with protection concerns in targeted locations, through -Conduct awareness-raising sessions on protection risks, avoidance, remedies with focusing on safety messages in pandemics -Establish Protection Help Desks and provide supportive information -Establish 2 multi-sectoral referral pathways and service mapping in the targeted locations, -Support protection committees to work on concerns related to COVID 19 -Conduct periodic KII and report to PMTF on protection concerns -Conduct awareness-raising activities with Key messaging and community mobilization interventions on PSEA -Deliver comprehensive CM amp IPA services to most vulnerable people.
3-Mine action services: targeting 26030, “M:3015, W:3015, B:10000, G:10000” by providing risk education activities. Project will target most vulnerable and at-risk groups in the situation of COVID19, through tailoring the modality of delivering the activities, using following methods: -Conduct activities in small groups and keep the suitable required distance between participants taking into consideration all safety steps (gloves / Masks/ Sanitizer) -Conduct home visits to implement sessions in participant’s home as necessary -Deliver the activities through online methods: WhatsApp groups, social media platforms, online meetings, radio streaming (more details in other sectionsampannexs)

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Continuation of the provision of Integrated Protection and Legal Services to IDPs and Host Community members through a community center in Afrin District, Aleppo Governorate, and Jisr Ash Shugur District, Idleb Governorate in Northwest Syria.

description.narrative: This project aims to continue providing the integrated GBV and legal assistance services in the already existing two Community Centers that are funded by the UN/IOM and run by Hope Revival Organization (HRO) until the end of June 2020 in Darkoush community/Idleb, and Afrin community/Aleppo. SADA Organization (Prime applicant), in partnership with HRO (Sub-applicant), will share the responsibilities and follow a protection-centered and community-based approach to ensure that a greater number of Syrians have safe access to these services and their protection risks and vulnerability is further reduced. The community center aims to provide a space where men, women, boys, and girls can socialize and strengthen previously fractured social networks, gain access to specialized protection services including GBV case management, obtain specialized information/legal support on Civil Status Documentation (CSD)/Housing Land and Property (HLP), and receive information on services available in the wider area. SADAD will target men, women, girls, and boys including most vulnerable ones, inside and outside WGSS in CCs in the two locations with GBV awareness-raising sessions (entry point to identify protection cases, risks, and needs), life skills, vocational training, and free space activities including recreational and handcraft activities, to strengthen social inclusion and enhance prevention of negative social norms that underpin the normalization of GBV. While HRO will provide GBV Case Management, GBV Young Mother Club services, in addition to capacity building for GBV project staff and for frontline humanitarian workers including health staff on GBV related issues to empower the community members and enable them effectively contribute to the prevention and response to GBV issues. Dissemination of key messages on COVID-19 will always be considered in project sessions. To ensure the staff well-being and alleviate the stress, burnout, and anxiety produced by the outbreak of coronavirus. And as a specialized organization in MHPSS. HRO will support the project staff in Turkey and Syria with regular physical or remote self/staff-care sessions by specialized focal point. The two centers are located in safe and accessible locations. Activities are designed based on identified needs considering culture, context, age of beneficiaries. Coordination at the field and central level will be closely followed by SADAD and HRO to ensure the effective engagement of community members in project activities and that the project is smoothly progressing. Each partner will monitor and evaluate its activities by one MampE focal point who will coordinate with the MampE managers in Turkey, using MampE toolkits developed by GBV SC. Moreover, HRO will rely on Protection Cluster recommendations while monitoring the legal services and activities. The project manager/SADAD and project officer/HRO, in Turkey, will supervise and follow up on the day-to-day performance of field teams, work plans, safety and security measures and actions, HR, procurement, and finance-related tasks in coordination with the concern departments and with project field coordinators. SADAD and HRO program managers (in Turkey) will facilitate and lead the monthly review meetings to ensure that the project is on the right track in line with the overall objective, scope of work, timeline, and budget. GP (40), GBV (60).

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)
United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Strengthening Access to GBV, CP, and Protection Monitoring for Returnees and IDPs in Northwestern Syria Ariha.

description.narrative: Space of Peace (SOP) through this project aims at mitigating protection risks and responding to the critical protection needs in Ariha district, by providing life-saving and specialized Gender-Based Violence (GBV) services in Women and Girls Safe Space (WGSS) and child protection services in Child Safe Space (CFS). Through outreach teams in Ariha taking into consideration all the technical guidance notes of COVID 19, where the population of this area at high risk after their hard displacement experience recently. By the time they were able to return, COVID-19 pandemic emerged globally posing additional concern to them. This encouraged people to return to their demolished houses instead of facing the risk of infection in the camps. SOP has a presence in Ariha through protection projects in the area for 4 years ago and managed to build trust with the community. The center became known to all the different age and gender groups in the community. Our past protection interventions had a positive impact on the community in general and especially on women, girls, boys including PWD. The exacerbated needs and the staggering protections risk in this district have been identified through rapid assessments and stressed by the local council in Ariha that welcomed our return to the area to provide our usual services. Through this project, SOP will work to achieve the following outcomes, through operating static centers and mobile teams: 1) The safety, dignity, and well-being of vulnerable women and girls are improved. 2) Address the specific protection needs of children who are survivors or at risk of violence, abuse, and exploitation through providing quality-specialized child protection services. 3)The resilience of the local community is enhanced by providing lifesaving emergency protection services and protection monitoring. SOP will target in Ariha district 5 communities(Ariha, Motaram, Nahaleh, OrmEljoz, and Nahliya with a total population of 86843 people (17921 men, 20913 women, 28919 boys, 19090 girls). SOP will target 2737 women, 2865 girls, 1975 boys, and 713 men of returnees’ host communities and IDPs through this project with specialized and none specialized protection services three parts (GBV, CP, PM). GBV activities: The activities will be provided along with a full package of other services mitigating GBV risks through like awareness-raising sessions including GBV, SEA risks, group and individual PSS sessions, case management, referral services to survivors of GBV and empowering women, girls through life skills and vocational training. Mobile teams will be covering Ariha communities and will be reaching out to cover the proposed areas. We will also provide responses to GBV risks through case management and referral to other services. All these activities will implement according to GBV SC guidance note on GBV service provision in the time of COVID-19 and IASC Interim Guidance on COVID-19 – Protection from Sexual Exploitation and Abuse. CP activities: SOP will be providing specialized case management services to high-risk cases including UASC, child labor, disability, physical/psychological injuries, and referrals to other services including LH, Education, MHPSS, Health…etc. SOP will also be providing remote-based structured and sustained PSS programs utilizing the guidance shared by the CP SC. Moreover, SOP will target children and caregivers with an awareness-raising program on main CP related concerns. In addition, SOP will be distributing age-appropriate (54) PSS kits to the targeted children and adolescents through a door-to-door approach in order to minimize physical contact with beneficiaries and will take into account COVID-19 related considerations. SOP will conduct protection monitoring in collaboration with PMTF, SOP field team will collect information on the protection risks in Ariha, identify risks like the restriction of movement, lack of civil documentation, lack of social structures and so on

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)
United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Increasing self-resilience of the persons with functional difficulties by providing prosthetics and creating inclusive protective environments through community and beneficiary participation

description.narrative:
The proposed project will form a complementary part of HIHFAD on-going comprehensive supports to survivors of ERW and other conflict-related and nonrelated injuries (mobile outreach service, fixed rehabilitation service, prosthetic service, inclusion mainstreaming and peers counselling) with multiple partners. In addition, the project emphasis on participation of the beneficiaries themselves and the community members to harness inclusive and protective environments in the target communities through establishment of community networks on inclusion and case management.
Building on HIHFAD’s previous success in harnessing self-reliance and self-confidence among the most marginalized group, the proposed project aims at increasing self-resilience of the persons with disabilities and creating inclusive and protective environments through community and beneficiary participation. Through three inter-connected components 1) Benefiting and empowering people with amputations directly through prosthetic supports in Northwest Syria. 2) Enhancing community-based inclusive approach and protection among the local communities and local NGOs through creating community inclusion networks. 3) Providing customized supports of their choices to the persons with functional disabilities through case managements
1-Provison of 200 prosthesis in Albab city (8 months) This project is a co-fund to operate Al Bab Center for additional 8 months between November 2020 and June 2021(the center is funded till Oct 2020 by HALO Trust)During 8 months, the center will install 200 prosthesis. The beneficiaries will be selected from HIHFAD beneficiary list or through referral channels, after determining their ability to receive a prosthetic limb based on their K-level(a rating system used to indicate a person's rehabilitation potential). The selected beneficiaries will undertake required physical rehabilitation at the HIHFAD rehabilitation centre prior to receiving prosthetics. Transportation will be provided for the beneficiaries in need throughout the whole process.
2- Enhancing community-based inclusive approach (12 months) The project will target 14 community, 1 inclusion network will be established in each community consisting of people with and without functional difficulties. They will first undertake inclusion training for themselves, and later, they will actively engage in planning and conducting of the following tasks: - Plan and provide training and awareness sessions on inclusion of people with disabilities. - Identify and refer people with disabilities - Become an agent of advocacy in their communities for rights of people with disabilities -Plan and conduct community events of their choices. In addition, the project will conduct evidence-collection activity to compile lessons learned from community-based inclusive approach. 3 - Case Management and Protection Assistance: 300 beneficiaries and their families among the most vulnerable households will benefit through case management, offering PSS sessions, protection assistance, referrals, specialized service and access to socio-economic activities. The beneficiaries can request their choices of supports, which will be assessed and verified by the committees (HIHFAD staff and community members). This could include items to immediately reduce constrains faced by the most vulnerable households or more resilience-focused choices such as skill training, livelihood kits accelerated education. An average value of 180USD per person will be allocated for multi-purpose assistance through case management. The coronavirus pandemic expands an existing gap in the provision of this project services.This project was designed taking into consideration the expanded needs. The mentioned activities will take place in Aleppo/Afrin/Afrin- Jandairis- Sharan, Aleppo / Alabab/Albab, Aleppo /Jabel Samman/Atareb, Idleb/Harim/Dana,Idleb- Maaret Tamsrin

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision GBV Services through Mobile Teams in Northwest Syria

description.narrative: Maram Foundation will work through this project to reduce GBV effect by targeting vulnerable and conflict-affected IDPs in13 widows' camps in Idleb, Al Dana (Atma, Aqrabat, Qah, Babesqa, Deir Hassan), as well as the surrounding camps, 23500 BNFs (7500 girls, 12000 women,1800 boys amp 2200 men) including 1446 families (4865 of widows). The provision of GBV services in these areas will respond to critical issues, mainly discrimination, violence, economic exploitation, movement restrictions, SEA, forced and early marriage those widows, girls and PWDs exposed to, according to the data collected. It will also focus on strengthening elements of the preparedness and response to the COVID-19 pandemic as well as to adapt activities according to the GBV SC guidance note on COVID19. In addition, this project will be complementary with existing projects in the targeted areas (MF WGSS centres: Jasmin 2amp4). MF conducts all activities in close coordination with local actors, and according to the Guidance Note: Mitigating Protection Risks in IDP Sites, many stakeholders share the responsibility of ensuring the protection of affected populations throughout the entire life cycle of a site /Feb2019/. MF has running projects in the targeted locations and two WGSS centres (the first WGSSs in this area) including midwives who provide simple services of RH. MF also ensures coordination with organizations working in the same region and/or protection, GBV actors. MF is conducting activities in 9 widows’ camps through WGSSs ongoing project since Jan 2020, with permission renewed on monthly basis. During May 2020 an assessment took place, recommendations mentioned the necessity of Safe Spaces inside widows’ camps (Annex 3), which include lessons learned and solutions suggested. The project will be implemented on stages: 1, coordinating with the camp administration in order to secure a place for the project activities that take into account the confidentiality amp safety of the activities. If no secured place, MF will create a tent as WGSS. 2, An elected committee of women amp girls including PWDs amp elderly women (in each camp), is going to participate in decision-making to determine the identity of the place, the type of activities, empowerment topics and future modality of their lifestyle. 3, 13 of mobile teams will be implementing the project’s activities, each team consists of a case manager who will provide CM both in-person and remotely, according to the COVID19 response stage outlined in the GBV SC guidance note of COVID-19, Also, PSS worker and female facilitator for each camp, and another male facilitator will be targeting men amp boys who live near the widows' camps, local authorities and councils. 4, MF will conduct empowerment courses for women, to enhance economic capacity, in order to rely on themselves, especially sewing, so they will have a role in producing masks as a kind of preparation to respond to the spread of the epidemic. 5, MF WGSSs will conduct training for medical workers and first responders in order to respond to GBV cases, especially in light of the spread of COVID19. Also, training for workers on PFA, GBV, PSEA referral mechanism and will focus on the activities that enhance the well-being of staff. MF has full access to widows’ camps, with solid relationships with local communities, camps management and IDP representation committees (Annex 8).In September 2019, GBV SC recommended MF as a reputable NGO with vast experience in protection and Gender-Based Violence programs, and proven accessibility in northwest Syria.MF has been identified and recommended by the GBV SC as a reputable NGO with vast experience in protection and GBV programs, and proven accessibility in NW Syria. Also, are firmly committed to the global fight to eradicate SEA and have 4 technical acting members within the UN-OCHA PSEA meetings.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Promote and Strengthen Community-Based protection interventions and Providing Individually Life-Saving Protection Services in NWS.

description.narrative: Starting from the priorities identified by the protection cluster and sub-clusters, and as per the findings of the need’s assessments conducted in the last period, SEMA, under the support of SCHF, seeks to provide life-saving protection services in the following two components: 1- CP Services: implemented by SEMA and SANAD which includes the following: Continuity of ongoing activities and projects that include existing case management teams and CFS at Afrin and A’zaz districts, which are currently under the support of SCHF through USSOM till the end of July. As SEMA, in partnership with SANAD organization, aims to continue operating the existed two Amal centers in Moaz Abo Mehdi Hospital and introduce CP case management, awareness, identification and referral through the static and mobile teams, where SANAD team will provide Special need rehabilitation program (SNR) for CWD, and their parents. AMAL center in Sharan will continue provision its specialized services with expansion in adding a safe space for PSS activities and 2 outreach teams witch will provide awareness raising sessions ,recreational activities and identification and referral for at risk CP cases. Establishment of CP services focusing on specialized service at Al-Bab Sub-district, where a new CFS will be established and case management, referral, PSS and awareness sessions’ activities will be delivered through static and mobile teams. Case management activities will continue to address CP concerns including worst forms of child labor, neglect, child marriage and CAAFAG in addition to those aggravated by COVID-19 such as family separation or children left without their primary caregiver due to illness, hospitalization or bereavement/death of a parent or primary caregivers, risk of neglect, domestic violence, exploitation, and psychological distress. SEMA will continue mobilizing its Health, Nutrition, Physiotherapy, and MHPSS services which formed a strong internal referral system in addition to the effective external referral system for specialized and nonspecialized services already exist. More details about the activities of SANAD and the added value for partnership with them is uploaded in "Documents" tab. Already existed CPN (and a new one will be established in Albab), will be utilized to be able to raise the awareness of affected communities on CP concerns, awareness about seriousness of health, contagion risks of COVID–19 outbreak and safety measures and precautions. Supervision mechanism will continue supporting Case managers in providing safe, ethical, and competent services. SEMA team will continue in contributing in CPM as a member of the taskforce. During the implementation of all activities precaution measures will be taken as per WHO guidelines, where teams will be trained and provided with PPE. In case of COVID-19 spreads activities will be conducted online through WhatsApp groups. 2- Gender Based Violence: Implemented by HRO from the beginning of July. SEMA in partnership with Hope Revival Organization, the sub-implementing partner, aims to maintain and enhance the safe access of GBV case management and Women and Girl’s Safe Spaces (WGSS) of affected women and girls especially those with special needs in both already functioning centers is Jisr Ash Shugur Community and Kafr Jales Community. Life Skills, awareness-raising through outreach (entry point to identify GBV cases, risks, and needs), case management, empowerment, training of GBV and non GBV actors, and safety audits are some of the key activities in addition to working with existing community committees and focusing on community engagement and to take part in designing and implementation. More details about the HRO activities and the added value for partnership with them is also uploaded in "Documents" tab.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)
United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance access to life-saving community-based protection services (GBV MA) for IDPs and host communities in four locations in northwest Syria.

description.narrative: WSA runs three WGSSs in Bennish, KafrTakarim, and Kaferlucin in Idleb, NW Syria, and plans to continue implementing activities through providing protection services for women and girls affected by the crisis, including GBV survivors and persons affected by war injuries and mild physical disabilities. These are backed by Casualty Data Collection that is going to be shared with IMSMA and to help in identifying cases and needs for planning. Besides the three mentioned locations, our partner NAS will conduct RE and VDC services in Idlib sub-district. COVID-19 awareness messages -and prevention procedures- will be put into consideration in all activities. The WGSS in Bennish, provides protection services for WampG, in line with the UNFPA Guidelines, including WampG with a mild physical disability. The center contributes to the promotion of services and measures of MA and quality GBV services providing appropriate services to prevent and reduce the risks of GBV, ERW, and COVID-19 in the mentioned location. The center offers child care to improve access for women with little children, besides an outreach service through trained mobile teams that can reach beneficiaries who cannot come, or have no access, to the center. According to the latest developments regarding the global pandemic of Coronavirus, the WHO guidelines, and following the guidance note on the provision of GBV and MA services during the COVID-19 Pandemic, developed by the GBV and MA SCs WSA has begun to provide the services by reducing the number of beneficiaries inside the centers and increase the outreach activities, taking into account the recommended prevention measures. In terms of the other two locations (in KafrTakarim and Kaferlucin), MA service will be provided, including RE and VDC, plus referring cases in need of individual assistance. These services are going to be provided through fixed and outreach activities. Indoor activities: Train teams on how to prevent COVID-19 and RE communicating messages to beneficiaries (IDPs, host community, and humanitarian actors), casualty surveys, GBV, and RE. Provide specialized GBV services and CM, in addition to group and specialized individual PSS. 2 CM workers will follow up with the WampG-GBV survivors- including survivors of ERW accidents and affected by war injuries and mild physical disabilities. In addition to providing direct support service and referrals to other services according to the referral paths that are shared by the sub-clusters, and service mapping through coordination with actors in the area, continuously updated. Provide vocational training (sewing) for the most vulnerable WampG. Case management principles to be followed, privacy, informed, a survivor code. All case-related files are kept confidentially in a locked cabinet and are periodically destroyed after e-copies are held secured, where only the CW and the T-supervisor can reach them. Preventive activities, such as life skills (My safety my wellbeing) and recreational activities, young mother’s club in coordination with SRD and CARE. Distribution of awareness GBV (GBV-SC package), RE (MASC messages), Covid19 (WHO tools) brochures. Refer cases/victims in need of individual assistance (VA). Outreach activities: Provide emergency response for WampG: PFA, CM and referral, registration for GBV cases, and VDC for ERW survivors. Conduct awareness sessions for Covid19, using posters in the camps. Training sessions for non-specialized service providers in the field of GBV, RE, and Covid19 prevention measures, with a focus on health staff, on best practices in dealing with GBV and ERW survivors.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing essential general protection and child protection services to conflict-affected girls, women, boys, and men in Idleb, Ariha and Jisr-Ash- Shugur

description.narrative: Syria Relief SR aims to continue providing General Protection and Child Protection services in south and west Idleb, after starting delivering those services in north Idleb under the 1st RA 2020. The project aims to deliver planned services to most vulnerable Girls, Boys, Women and Men GBWM in Idleb, Ariha and Jisr-Ash- Shugur districts through 4 static community centres CCs within 4 relatively densely populated communities in addition to 4 mobile units. SR will ensure the services are accessible by PwDs and will consider all possible precautious measures (social distancing and using the PPE) and Cluster guidelines related to adapting Protection services delivery modalities in light with COVID-19, to ensure the safety of staff and beneficiaries and avoid causing harm (see attached SR COVID-19 Response Plan). The services will be delivered during 12 months starting from 1st of Jul-20, addressing the identified Protection and CP needs of targeted individuals. The Overall Project Objective is designed to provide integrated protection and CP services and coordinate closely with local service providers from other sectoral services (FSL amp Early Recovery, WASH, and Health-Nutrition actors) to facilitate access of persons with specific needs to those services. The outcome of the proposed intervention will be conflict-affected and most vulnerable GBWM, including PwD, have a better understanding of their rights and better resilience through benefitting from legal Protection, Protection and Child Protection services. This Outcome has been informed by the ASOs 1 and 2 as outlined in the 2020 1st Standard Allocation. SR aims at the continuation of protection activities within areas of operation. Besides, the protection teams will extend their reach into new subdistricts in Idleb governorate rated 4, 5 or 6/ 6 in the severity scale. Protection services are intended to provide a package of essential preventive and responsive services to affected Host communities, IDPs and Returnees through expanding the capacity of mobile outreach teams, reactivating Ariha centre (CFS), and launching new Protection activities in parallel with the existing Education activities that SR implements in Jisr-Ash- Shugur. The project is designed to reactivate Ariha static facility that SR evacuated in Oct-20 and add 1facility in Korin, 1 in Jisr-Ash-Shugur and the fourth facility in Hanbushiyeh. The 4 static facilities will be community hubs through which SR can identify and respond to most affected populations. 4 mobile units will be attached to those centres to reach out PwDs or those practising voluntary quarantine so they cannot visit the centres. The gender-mixed mobile units will also deliver the project services within 8 neighbouring communities. The proposed CCs and mobile units will provide many general protection and child protection services including awareness-raising about legal protection, general protection and CP concerns. SR Teams will also provide case management and IPA to the identified most vulnerable GWBM. PSS will be delivered to girls and boys. Besides, parents will have the opportunity to join positive parenting skills sessions. Training about HLP/CSD and CP will be delivered to concerned humanitarian workers to ensure they are well capacitated. Community-based Protection committees will be supported. Furthermore, the Protection Teams will be part of the current Cluster taskforces and collect data related to Protection Monitoring and Child Protection Situational Monitoring surveys. Emergency focal points will be assigned to contribute to Cluster efforts in coordinating the Protection response. Protection services will provide a secure and supportive environment, building on existing capacities within the local communities and expanding the population of SR response team. SR Protection Teams will implement all Project activities directly with support from SR Turkey Office.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing access to GBV prevention services in Western rural of Aleppo.

description.narrative:
The project endeavors to implement complemented activities in the humanitarian field in western rural of Aleppo province. This intervention will make contribution towards strengthening community-based protection interventions and life-saving protection assistance depending on the expansion of the activities of two existing protection centers WGSS specialized in GBV in Atareb and Kafr Karmin villages and conducting of outreach activities. The project will target women, men, older women, girls, boys, and people with disabilities and include implementation of the following activities: - Forming of two mobile teams in order to provide of psychological first aid (PFA), information/awareness, case management, GBV services, referrals to GBV services and other services. The teams will cover the Daret Azza and Atareb sub-district in rural Aleppo in addition to the surrounding camps.(every sub-team will consist of two mobile teams, two social workers and case management workers). - Providing support for case management activities (Case fund) for 100 survivors. This assistance will be provided in kind and cash and the amount estimated for each beneficiary is 100 USD. Based on Cash Assistance in GBV Case Management Guidance Note June, 2019.By GBV-sub cluster. - Engaging women and girls in making COVID-19 prevention IEC material “masks” where the women survivors and volunteers are not only contributing to protect the health of essential workers, they are also feeling empowered and valued. - Increasing availability of remote staff well-being services to support to all team members and keep them Productive by undertake a range of activities to improve their health and wellbeing. Ina addition to, collect, analyse, interpret, evaluate and present data regarding protection and wellbeing activities for reporting and decision-making purposes.
This intervention will support 14525 beneficiaries affected by the Syrian crisis (2942 men,5714 women, 2214 boys and 3655 girls) in Atareb and Daret Azza - sub-districts by promoting their accessibility to the protection assistance significantly. The project is designed to fit and be flexible to deal with conditions of constant changes and continuous of flows of IDPs who move between several locations. Also, the project team will ensure data protection, confidentiality at all stages, protocols of information sharing and acquiring informed consent from beneficiaries. The project activities will be in line with Protection Cluster Recommendations, SOPs, Inclusive COVID-19 response - NWS Disability - TWG on Inclusion Guidance Note April 2020 and GBV SC guidance note on GBV service provision in the time of COVID-19 such as Hand sanitizing when conducting the sessions/ Gathering of five beneficiaries per session and social distance/Measure the temperature for each beneficiary as a precaution/ Plan has been put for online sessions/ Put awareness posters about Corona disease during sessions.
MASRRAT is providing GBV service in Jabal Saman district by two WGSS centers in coordination with Ihsan and SRD. MASRRAT is a member of the protection cluster since 6 years ago and a focal point in Jebel Seman district to provide GBV services. This project will complement the ongoing UNFPA project through covering of more area of intervention in Jebel Samaan ,where the two teams will work together under the same management and technical support, also the project will support the centers by vocational activity. Each outreach team will be accompanied by a case manager who identifies the cases and coordinates with the GBV technical supervisor on UNFPA project to receive the cases in WGSS centers.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Delivery and integration of protection services to most at-risk and marginalized women and girls in greater Al Bab Sub-district.

description.narrative: The project will address the protection needs of both IDP and Host Communities in Albab subdistrict, northern Aleppo as a continuation of funding for Women and Girls Safe Space (WGSS) and affiliated community based outreach team. The WGSS started operating September 2018 funded by SCHF and continued until today with good acceptance from local community. SRD provides integrated protection activities within health facilities and stand-alone Women and Girls Safe Spaces (WGSS), providing response activities through a case management approach and a solid referral pathway in Albab city. A holistic and intensive model of case management will be utilized in the currently functional Women and Girls Safe Space in Al Bab city to enhance the resilience of survivors and vulnerable women and girls, specifically during COVID-19 pandemic.
